Actual reliance of catalytic activities tuned oxygen vacancies on VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalyst for selective oxydehydrogenation of methanol to dimethoxymethane Naseer Ahmad Safi Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Visualization Software Resources Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization Jia Ren Writing – review & editing Software Data curation Feng Xin Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Data curation ⁎ School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Metal oxide catalysts like ceria-supported vanadia (VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2) with different Zr contents were prepared by coupling ceria-zirconia solid solution and vanadia. Characterization revealed that the insertion of zirconia into ceria significantly improved catalytic activity due to the generation of more oxygen vacancies and distortion of the composite structure. The oxygen vacancy concentration initially increased with the increase of Zr (x= wt%) and peaked at x=0.7 and then decreased. The reliance of oxygen vacancy concentration in VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalyst on their catalytic activity in methanol oxydehydrogenation was further investigated. Results indicated that oxygen vacancies not only activated oxygen species but also cleaved C–H bonds alongside V5+ active site contained terminal oxygen atoms for cleaving O–H and C–H bonds within the adsorbed methanol. The VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 exhibited the best catalytic activity with the methanol conversion of 76 % and the dimethoxymethane selectivity of 96 % at 200 ℃ and atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed reactor. Graphical Abstract A series of vanadium-based catalyst with abundant surface oxygen vacancies, supported on ceria-zirconia solid solution with varying Zr contents and moderate acidity, were prepared. These catalysts to contribute to a well-matched kinetic profile between oxydehydrogenation of methanol and the condensation of formaldehyde and methanol, thus affording an effective bifunctional catalyst for the highly selective conversion of methanol to dimethoxymethane. Keywords Oxygen vacancy Methanol Catalytic oxydehydrogenation Zr-doped CeO2 Dimethoxymethane Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Dimethoxymethane (DMM) is predominantly used as an excellent solvent, and it is also considered as a potential feedstock to produce high value-added chemicals, such as glycol, formaldehyde, polyoxymethylene dimethylethers (PODE3–5), etc [1–3]. Among them, PODE3–5 can be also used as a diesel fuel additive due to its high oxygen content and the absence of C–C bonds in the structure, and thus enhance combustion proficiency and reduce NOx emission from engine exhaust. More importantly, incorporating 35 vol% PODE3–5 into standard diesel fuel results in a 90 % reduction in soot formation and significantly suppresses NOx emissions, decreasing them from 0.4 to 0.1 g kW–1 h–1. Therefore, the synthesis of PODE3–5 has attracted increasing attention [4–7]. Recently, a single-stage methanol catalytic oxidation was developed as one of the most advanced technologies to efficiently produce DMM. Some catalysts are used in this one-step approach, including FeVPW [8], Re/γ-Fe2O3 [9], VOx/TS-1 [10], V2O5-MoO3/γ-Al2O3 [11], V2O5/TiO2 [12], and SO4 2–/V2O5-ZrO2 [13]. However, the major challenge in methanol oxydehydrogenation to DMM is to find a high-efficient catalyst that can effectively increase methanol conversion and high DMM selectivity; nevertheless, in the single-step production of DMM from methanol, high DMM selectivity has been achieved, whereas the methanol conversion rate remains low. Consequently, rare earth and transition metal oxides, distinguished by their exceptional redox capabilities and oxygen storage capacity (OSC), include CeO2, which is extensively employed in various reactions as a catalyst or catalyst support [14–16]. This is attributed to its outstanding oxygen storage/release capacity and redox properties [17,18], whereas it has been relatively less researched as a support for vanadia than other oxide supports. Previous studies indicate that ceria-supported vanadia exhibits high activity and selectivity in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane, propane, and methanol [15,19,20]. Despite efforts to understand the interaction between vanadia and ceria, the structure of vanadia-dispersed species on the ceria surface has not been fully determined. The interaction between vanadia and ceria was studied trough DFT calculation, it was suggested that the catalytic performance of VOx/CeO2 toward methanol oxidation is highly consistent with its V–O–Ce interfacial sites, which were beneficial to the adsorption and activation of O2 and methanol [21–23]. Moreover, K. Yu et al. studied the role of Bi-doping in Pt/3DOM-Ce1-xBixO2-δ catalysts for aerobic HMF oxidation to form asymmetric oxygen vacancies (e.g., Bi–O(–Ce)3). The main advantage of these clusters, compared to symmetric ones (Ce–O–Ce), is that they offer metastable oxygen states, facilitating easy oxygen exchange [24]. In addition, P.H. Li et al. investigated the role of surface oxygen vacancies (OVs) and Ce ions in Ce-doped α-MoO3 nanorods. They found that Ce doping generated OVs on the C9M surface, enhancing Pb(II) adsorption and forming Pb–O bonds, thereby accelerating electrochemical redox reactions [25]. Additionally, it is proposed that gaseous O2 can be completely converted to lattice oxygen using oxygen vacancies as binding sites, thereby facilitating the cleavage of C–H bonds [26–28]. Moreover, Koller et al. further proposed through density functional theory (DFT) calculations that the formation of surface oxygen vacancies could increase the carrier density of the CeO2 system, thereby promoting the adsorption of O2 [29]. However, the insertion of Zr(IV) into ceria lattice could increase the OSC and thermal stability of CeO2 [30]. Safi [31]. suggested that the introduction of Zr into CeO2 could generate more oxygen vacancies due to the smaller ionic radii and structural distortion [32]. Moreover, the distortion by Zr of sublattice oxygen in ceria-zirconia solid solutions boosts the mobility of lattice oxygen, and thus the reduction of ceria-zirconia solid solutions occurs not only on the surface but also continues to the bulk [33,34]. Furthermore, H. Bao et al. investigated the microstructure-reducibility relationship of ceria-zirconia and proposed that doping Zr(IV) at the substitution site in CeO2 primarily enhances Ce(IV) reducibility. Additionally, Zr(IV) doping at the interstitial site lowers the activation energy of the reduction reaction while simultaneously increasing Ce(IV) reducibility [35]. O. Phichairatanaphong et al. studied the impact of the Ce/Zr ratio and template pH values in (Ni/CeZr(x)) catalysts on the dry reforming of CH4 and CO2, and suggested that the highest activity and stability, attributed to its high surface oxygen vacancies and basic sites [36]. However, based on the above studies, vanadia supported on ceria-zirconia solid solution (Ce1-xZrxO2) modified with SO4 2–, which should be an optimal catalyst with dual functions (VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2) to affectively catalyze the methanol oxydehydrogenation and condensation reaction, discerning the well matching of the reaction kinetics between two individual reactions observed in the selective oxydehydrogenation of methanol. Nevertheless, the reliance of oxygen vacancy concentration in VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 on its catalytic performance in methanol oxidation to DMM has not been systematically investigated. Therefore, the VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalyst was synthesized through precipitation and impregnation methods, presents a promising approach to generate more oxygen vacancies, and the reliance of oxygen vacancy concentration in VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 on its catalytic activity was deeply investigated. The concentration of oxygen vacancy on the surface of VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 can be adjusted by changing the Zr content. Which was beneficial beside the VOx species for adsorbing and activating the methanol and O2, facilitating its dissociative adsorption to produce formaldehyde, subsequently followed by rapid migration towards the acidic sites for final condensation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Source of reagents Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O), Zirconium nitrate pentahydrate (Zr(NO3)4·5 H2O) and Ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3) were purchased From Shanghai Meryer Co., Ltd. Sulfuric acid (H2SO4) was purchased from Tianjin Jiangtian Co., Ltd. Ammonia solution was purchased from Shanghai YiEn Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. The Air was purchase from Tianjin Dongrun Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Syntheses of catalysts A series of bare and zirconia-doped CeO2 were synthesized through template assisted chemical precipitation method. The ratio of Ce and Zr was carefully controlled by adjusting the molar concentrations of cerium nitrate and zirconium nitrate in the solution. Typically, 2 mmol of Ce (NO3)3 ⋅6 H2O and Zr (NO3)4 ⋅5H2O mixture were dissolved in 40 ml of deionized water, following by adding 2.5 ml H2O2 (30 %, Hydrogen peroxide acts as an oxidizing agent, which can facilitate the oxidation of cerium from Ce3+ to Ce4+ oxidation state) and 8 g of PEG-4000 (Polyethylene glycol serves as a template or structure-directing agent, its long polymer chains can help in controlling the morphology and size of the CeO2 and ZrO2 particles by preventing agglomeration and ensuring the particles are well-dispersed). Then, an ammonia solution (NH3 ⋅H2O, 25 %) was added dropwise under violent stirring at 80 ℃, and the mixture was kept stirring at 80 ℃ for 12 h. the obtained solid was filtered and washed with deionized water and ethanol for three times respectively, afterward drying at 100 ℃ for 12 h, and then calcinated in air at 500 ℃ for 5 h. The corresponding vanadia-sulfated catalysts were prepared as: 1.0 g of (Ce1-xZrxO2) and 1.0 g of NH4VO3 were dissolved in 10 ml 23 % aqueous solution of H2SO4, stirring at room temperature overnight. Thereafter, the mixture was filtered and washed with water (DI), followed by drying for 10 h at 100 ℃ and calcinated in air at 500 ℃ for 4 h. For the ceria-zirconia solid solution, the Zr doping level represent as Ce1-xZrxO2 (x=0, 0.5, 0.6, 0.7, and 0.8), and the correlated samples donated as VOx/CeO2, VOx/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2, VOx/Ce0.4Zr0.6O2, VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 and VOx/Ce0.2Zr0.8O2 respectively. 2.3 Characterizations All as prepared catalysts were characterized by ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis, UV-2550), X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker Nonius D8-Focus), Energy dispersion spectrometer (HAADF-STEM) equipped with a field emission scanning electron microscope and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-F200), X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Thermo icolet 380) were carried out to adjust the binding energy by C1s wire (284.8 eV) and the In-situ DRIFTS measurements were performed on an FTIR spectrometer (Thermo iS10) to verify the reaction pathways. After being put inside the sample chamber, the sample was air-purged. Afterwards, the temperature was raised to 200 °C and a continuous flow of methanol /air was introduced into the sample chamber. The scans were collected from 500 to 4000 cm–1 at a resolution of 4 cm–1. 2.4 Catalyst test and analytic procedures The selective oxydehydrogenation of methanol to dimethoxymethane (DMM) was conducted in a fixed-bed reactor, which consists of a stainless-steel tube with an inner diameter of 10 mm. In a typical method, 0.1 g of catalyst powder, mixed with 0.9 g of 100-mesh silicon carbide (SiC), was loaded into the central region of the reaction tube, and the catalyst was sealed at both ends by quartz wool. Methanol was introduced into the reactor by a pump, with a controlled flow rate of 0.01 ml/min. Concurrently, the flow rate of air was regulated to 4.5 ml/min, facilitated by a mass flow meter. To avert the polymerization of formaldehyde and subsequent obstruction of pipelines, the temperatures of all conduits downstream of the preheater were diligently maintained at 140 ℃. The reaction in this study was conducted at 200 ℃ and atmospheric pressure. The concentrations of reactants and products were assessed using an online gas chromatograph (GC-2030) featuring a heart-cut system (HCS). Methanol (MeOH, CH3OH), formaldehyde (FA, CH2O), dimethoxymethane (DMM, CH3OCH2OCH3), dimethyl ether (DME, CH3OCH3), and methyl formate (MF, CHOOCH3) were separated through a Polt Q capillary column and detected utilizing flame ionization detector (FID). The conversion of methanol and product selectivity were determined through carbon balance calculations, while quantification of all components was achieved using the absolute determining factor. The indicators of methanol conversion (XMeOH) and selectivity of each product (S) is equal to the molar amount of carbon (NC = 3 NDMM+ 2 NMF + 2 NDME) in each product, and the relevant calculation approach is as follows. X MeOH = [ N C / ( N MeOH + N C ) ] × 100 % S i = ( n i N i ) outlet 3 N DMM + 2 N MF + 2 N DME outlet × 100 % Where Si means the selectivity of dimethoxymethane (SDMM), the selectivity of methyl formate (SMF), the selectivity of dimethyl ether (SDME), while n i outlet is 3, 2 and 2 for i being DMM, MF and DME respectively regarding the carbon balance in each individual product at the outlet. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations According to the XRD patterns ( Fig. 1) of bare VOx/CeO2 and zirconia-doped VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalysts, all samples exhibited a crystalline cubic fluorite structure with a space group of Fm3m (JCPDS PDF# 43–1002). The characteristic peaks corresponding to the (miller indices) crystal planes of CeO2, namely (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), and (420), are observed at 28.5, 33.08, 47.48, 56.38, 69.4, 76.8, 79.08, and 88.4, respectively (Fig. 1a) [37]. This suggests that the insertion of Zr into CeO2 lattice has little impact and provides evidence for the stability of the cubic fluorite structure after doping. No obvious independent peaks for Zr and/or V are observed, indicates that the Zr and V species are uniformly distributed in the ceria lattice for all samples. In addition, the characteristic peaks of doped ceria become slightly shifted toward higher angle contrast with bare ceria, which ascribed to the substitution of Ce4+ ions (0.97 Å) by smaller Zr4+ ions (0.84 Å) in the formation of ceria-zirconia solid solution, and that could lead to the shrinkage of lattice cell, this was consistent with the fact that the introduction of Zr into the CeO2 lattice could decreased the lattice parameter α from 5.4066 to 5.2470 Å [38–40]. In order to acquire more intuition of the crystal structural distortion induced by Zr doping, the Rietveld refinement technique was used to analyzing the XRD data of all VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 as-prepared catalysts (Fig. S1). The fitting results, illustrated in Fig. 1b, which demonstrate a relatively good fit with χ2 values below 1.5. These findings indicate that all samples exhibited a uniform phase with a Fm3m space group, and the addition of Zr did not induce any structural phase shift. The structural parameters, derived through Rietveld refinement and VESTA fitting, are delineated in the Table S1. The Ce−O bond length and unit cell volume exhibits a linearly decreasing correlation with the incorporation of Zr doping. The shrinkage of the unit cell after Zr doping was confirmed, thereby verifying the random and uniform distribution of Zr ions in the VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 material. In order to assess the morphological homogeneity and distribution of Zr species within VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 samples, representative specimens underwent examination through scanning TEM (STEM) and EDX, as shown in Figs. 2 and S2–5, respectively. As illustrated in Figs. 2a, and S2–5a, the TEM and HRTEM images of both bare VOx/CeO2 and doped VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 samples reveal, the interplanar spacing of 0.311 nm, 0.270 nm, 0.267 nm, 0.300 nm and 0.214 nm, corresponding to the 111, 100, 200, 311 and 110 lattice planes of cubic fluorite structure and vanadia, respectively. The determination was made using fast Fourier transform (FFT) and inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) methods. As can be seen from Fig. 2a, there are approximately spherical nanoparticles with an average diameter of 7.2 nm (the grain size calculated through TEM analysis). No large particles of Zr were observed in the VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 catalyst, indicating that the loading of Zr did not alter the catalyst morphology. Additionally, in Fig. S2b, the form of small amorphous aggregates of V2O5 on the surface of the support is well-distinguished, with single spots conforming to the cloud in the SAED pattern. However, due to the insertion of Zr into the ceria lattice, the particle average diameter gradually decreased ( Table 1), the aggregate becomes dissipated, which is clearly identified in the IFFT results. Furthermore, the uniform distribution of all constituent elements within bare VOx/CeO2 and doped VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 samples was verified through elemental mapping with Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS), thus reaffirming the formation of both bare and doped ceria solid solutions, as depicted in Figs. S2–5b, and S2c. Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was utilized to differentiate a variety of functional groups across the 4000–300 cm⁻¹ wavenumber range, as illustrated in Fig. 3, for both the bare VOx/CeO2 and doped VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 samples. The broad peak at 3600–3250 cm⁻¹ was assigned to –OH groups [41], while the peak at 1650 cm⁻¹ was ascribed to the bending mode of water molecules associated with sulfate groups [42], suggesting the presence of surface-adsorbed water molecules [43]. The observed peaks at 1390 and 1261 cm⁻¹ are ascribed to the existence of sulfate groups present on the catalyst surface. This observation typically aligns with the vibration frequency exhibited by bidentate or tridentate SO₄²⁻ species coordinated with surface cations, as reported in prior studies [44]. The spectral peak observed at 1030 cm−1 is associated with the isolated vanadyl (VO) non-bridge bonds situated within the [VO5] trigonal bipyramidal structure. Moreover, the identification of a distinct, sharply defined band at 570 cm⁻¹, ascribed to the stretching vibration of the Ce–O bond, confirms the formation of a solid solution of CeO2 [12]. UV–vis absorption spectroscopy was applied to determine the bare VOx/CeO2 and doped VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 sample’s optical properties, as shown in Fig. 4. In the UV–vis region, two main bands are observed at 300 and 370 nm. The peak at 300 nm corresponds to charge transfer (CT) transitions from O2− (2p) → Ce4+ (4 f) orbitals in CeO2 [37], while the peak at 370 nm is associated with oxygen–tetrahedral O2− →V5+ charge transfer (CT) transitions, containing bridging (V–O–Zr and/or V–O–Ce) and terminal vanadyl (VO) oxygens, respectively (Fig. 4a) [18]. For the bare sample, the broad and relatively high peak at the range of 367–530 nm is probably due to the aggregation and crystallinity of V species (Fig. 4b), which also observed in the SAED pattern of TEM analysis (Fig. S2b). Additionally, compared to the bare sample VOx/CeO2, an evident blue shift of the bands in the range of 440 and 520 nm can be observed in the magnified view of Fig. 4b, which indicates that the increase in Zr content within the ceria lattice could decrease the band gap, which is attributed to the substitution of Zr ions in the ceria lattice, leading to the generation of more oxygen vacancies, thus accelerating the electron transfer rate [25]. The oxidation activity of methanol to DMM is significantly influenced by the chemical state of V, Ce and Zr on the catalyst surface. Therefore, XPS analysis was conducted on both bare VOx/CeO2 and doped VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 samples, the binding energies and peak fitting are illustrated in Fig. 5. The XPS spectra of Ce3d can be categorized into five distinct doublets based on spin-orbit interactions (Fig. 5a). The peaks v0, v, v′, v″, and v″′ centered at 882.8, 884.3, 887.8, 889.3, and 898.1 eV corresponded to the Ce3d5/2 levels, while the peaks u0, u, u′, u″, and u″′ located at 900.1, 902, 906.5, 907.8, and 916.6 eV correlated to the Ce3d3/2 levels [31,40]. Among them, the three pairs of peaks, namely v-u, v″-u″, and v″′-u″′ can be attributed to the final three states (Ce3d94 f2O2p4), (Ce3d94 f1O2p5), and (Ce3d94 f0O2p6) of the Ce4+ species, respectively. The two pairs of peaks v0-u0 and v′-u′ can be attributed to the final states of Ce3+ species, specifically Ce3d94 f2O2p5 and Ce3d94 f1O2p6, respectively [45]. Hence, it can be affirmed that both Ce4+ and Ce3+ species coexist on the catalyst surfaces. It was known that the concentration of oxygen vacancies is directly associated with the Ce3+ ions on the catalysts surface [24]. Hence, the relative content of Ce3+ was subsequently calculated by assessing the integrated area (Ai) of each peak as [Ce3+]/[Ce3++Ce4+], and the findings are presented in Table 1. As shown in Table 1, the assembly of Ce3+ in bare VOx/CeO2 is significantly lower than that in doped VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2, indicating that VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 has a higher number of oxygen vacancies. In the VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 samples, the concentration of Ce3+ exhibits an ascending trend concomitant with the introduction of Zr, attaining its pinnacle for VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2. Subsequently, the concentration undergoes a decline upon further increase in Zr content. This suggests that a further increase in Zr content causes the segregation phenomenon, which suppresses the formation of asymmetric (Ce–O–Zr) sites and generates symmetric (Zr–O–Zr sites. Additionally, previous studies have shown that oxygen atoms at the metal/oxide interface, which are asymmetrically bonded and connected to coordinatively unsaturated cations, exhibit high activity for catalytic oxidation reactions [46,47]. Fig. S6. Illustrates the Zr3d spectral structure of VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalysts. The discernible peaks observed at 181.9 ∼ 182.2 and 184.2 ∼ 184.5 eV correspond to Zr3d5/2 and Zr3d3/2, respectively [36]. These peaks can be ascribed to the presence of Zr species in the Zr4+ oxidation state on the catalyst surfaces. Moreover, a noticeable shift to higher binding energies is observed for VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 (181.9 eV→182.2 eV, 184.2 eV→184.5 eV) compared to other samples, indicating a robust connection between Ce and Zr through electron transfer [48]. Furthermore, Zr4+ penetration into the CeO2 lattice leads to the formation of a solid solution structure, thereby increasing the electron density. This phenomenon further elucidates the observed increment in oxygen vacancies. The O1s spectra of the samples are shown in Fig. 5b. The peaks centered at 529.2–529.8 eV and 529.9–531.3 eV could be attributed to the lattice oxygen species (O2−, labeled as β) and defect oxygen or chemisorbed oxygen species (O2 2− and O2−, labeled as α) on the surface of both bare VOx/CeO2 and doped VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 samples, respectively. Furthermore, the calculation of the oxygen vacancy concentration on the sample surface was determined as [OV] % = [Aα] / [Aβ + Aα], derived from the integrated regions of lattice and defect oxygen [37]. The corresponding results are presented in Table 1. As shown, remarkable differences are observed between the bare VOx/CeO2 and doped VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 samples. The percentage of defect oxygen species gradually increased with increasing Zr content 28–36.4 %, and then decreased. This may be related with the change in the electron density of Zr. The V2p3/2 XPS spectra of bare VOx/CeO2 and doped VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 samples are illustrated in Fig. S7. From the deconvolution results of V2p3/2, the highest amount of V4+ species is presents on the VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 surface among the all samples (Table 1), indicating that the V2O5 reduction degree further enhanced with the insertion of Zr content into the support. Based on the XPS analysis, the interaction of VOx species with the ceria and zirconia on the catalyst surface tends to enhance the reduction of Ce and V species. The augmentation in catalytic activity was attributed to the generation of complementary Ce3+ and V4+ substances. Particularly, the VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 catalyst exhibited higher concentration of Ce3+ (39.1 %) and V4+ (38 %) species as well as higher chemisorbed oxygen (36.4 %) species than the other samples. It is suggested that partially reduced Ce and V could enhance methanol oxydehydrogenation activity. The observed activity improvement could be attributed to the generation of more oxygen vacancies as asymmetric (Vn+/Ce–O–Zr) sites, as the oxygen atoms in these sites are much more active than the lattice oxygen in metal/oxide structures, thereby increasing the adsorption capacity for molecular oxygen and methanol [17,49–51]. To gain deeper insights into the formation of crystal defects induced by Zr doping, the VOx/Ce₁₋ₓZrₓO₂ materials were examined using Raman spectroscopy. As depicted in the Fig. 6, the prominent band at approximately 443 cm⁻¹ in the Raman spectra of all samples is associated with the F2 g mode of the fluorite-type ceria lattice. A gradual redshift of this band observed upon Zr4+ doping implies a change in the Ce−O bonding symmetry likely due to the embedding of Zr4+ ions into the crystalline lattice of CeO2 [21,52]. Moreover, the band at 550 cm⁻¹, which becomes more pronounced with increasing Zr content, is attributed to Ce3+−O bonds associated with oxygen vacancy (D mode) sites induced by Zr4+ doping. These vacancy sites likely include asymmetric Ce−O−Zr sites within the bulk phase and (Vn+/Ce–O–Zr) sites on the surface of the VOx/Cex-1ZrxO2 samples. Notably, a broad band at approximately 550 cm⁻¹ is particularly evident in the spectrum of VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2, suggesting a relatively high concentration of oxygen vacancies. This observation is consistent with the results of the XPS analysis results presented in Table 1 [34,45,53]. As shown in the magnified inset, oxygen vacancies significantly increase after Zr doping. All spectra were fitted to calculate the ID/IF2g ratios for quantitative analysis (Fig. S8). The results display that the content of oxygen vacancies shows a distinct volcanic curve due to the increased actual doping amount in VOx/Cex-1ZrxO2 in Table S4. Therefore, it can be concluded that the oxygen vacancies in VOx/Cex-1ZrxO2 are higher than in VOx/CeO2, which supports better performance in the oxidehydrogenation of methanol to DMM. 3.2 Catalytic activity of VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 in the oxydehydrogenation of methanol The dependance of oxygen vacancy concentration in VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalyst on their catalytic activity during methanol oxydehydrogenation is shown in Table S2, which presents the catalytic efficiency of all synthesized catalysts. While VOx/CeO2 catalyst exhibit high DMM selectivity, the methanol conversion rate is low. The insertion of Zr enhances the Ce3+/[Ce3++Ce4+] ratio, as presented in Table 1. An increase in the Ce3+ concentration relative to Ce4+ leads to a significant enhancement in the catalytic performance, indicating the crucial role of Ce3+ in the catalytic properties. This increase provides more asymmetric (Vn+/Ce–O–Zr) sites, facilitating electron transfer and improving the catalytic efficiency of the synthetic catalysts. Thus, the methanol conversion rate is improved while maintaining high DMM selectivity; the highest conversion is obtained when the Zr content is at (x=0.7). Further increasing the Zr content to (x=0.8) resulted in a significant reduction in catalytic activity. This suggests that catalytic activity is influenced not only by the quantity of oxygen vacancies but also by the local environment of the vacancy (Vn+/Zr–O–Zr) sites. The site symmetry of the oxygen vacancies increases when new clusters containing Zr cations form at high dopant concentrations, thereby affecting the overall catalytic performance. Therefore, the observed conversion trend consistently aligns with the optimized concentration of oxygen vacancy (Vn+/Ce–O–Zr) sites on the VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 catalyst surfaces. Previous studies indicate that the introduction of Zr into the VOx/CeO2 catalyst not only enhance the oxygen vacancies but also promote the reducibility of VOx species on the catalyst surface, thus generate more formaldehyde [54]. Fig. 7 illustrates the catalytic efficiency of different VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalysts as they varied over time on stream (TOS). Within 26 h, there was no considerable change in the catalytic performance of the catalysts, suggesting that the catalysts exhibited a high level of stability. As shown in Fig. 8, all the composites showed high catalytic activity and stability during the oxydehydrogenation of methanol. However, the methanol conversion gradually increases with the increasing Zr content and reaches a maximum for (x=0.7). With the increment of Zr content from 0.5 to 0.7 in VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2, the selectivity of methyl formate dropped from 20.5 % to 1.2 %, and the selectivity of dimethyl either remained below 1 %. This suggests that the undesired reaction of methanol to MF and DME was inhibited. It is well-known that the formate species, the main component of methyl formate, is crucial for the formation of formic acid [12]. Simultaneously, the selectivity toward DMM was remarkably improved. Thus, the insertion of Zr not only suppresses the oxidation of dioxymethylene species but also promotes the nucleophilic assault on the dioxymethylene carbon atom by the oxygen atoms of adsorbed methanol molecules. In addition, according to previous studies, the rate-limiting step of methanol oxidation to DMM is the conversion of methanol into formaldehyde intermediate through the entire process, which has a high energy barrier than the formaldehyde and methanol reaction to DMM [55]. Hence, the high conversion methanol to DMM mainly relied on the quantity of oxygen vacancies (Vn+/Ce–O–Zr) present on the VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 surface. The recycle stability of VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 was evaluated through a continuous 26-hours stability experiment utilizing a mixture of 0.1 g VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 and 0.9 g SiC, as illustrated in Fig. S9. At 200 ℃ VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 exhibited excellent recycle stability, with no significant decline observed in methanol catalytic conversion and DMM selectivity, maintaining above 95 % selectivity for DMM and 75 % conversion for methanol. 3.3 Adsorption behavior of methanol on the catalyst surface In order to get more insight of methanol adsorption behavior on the catalyst. Therefore, the adsorption process was online analysis at 200 ℃ in-situ with the aid of a diffuse reflectance Fourier In-situ DRIFTS instrument, as shown in Fig. 9. Based on previous studies, the peak centered at 3440 cm–1 corresponded to the tensile vibration bond of –OH groups of adsorbed methanol molecules [8]. The peaks centered at 2966 cm–1 and 2848 cm–1 corresponded to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration bonds of the –C–H in adsorbed methanol and methoxy groups of the methanol molecules respectively [56]. The peak at 2005 cm–1 corresponded to the tensile vibration of –OH on the formate group. As the adsorption time prolonging, the new peak appearance at 1750 cm–1 indexed to the carbonyl group, and the peak situated at 1562 cm–1 belongs to –COO–, and the vibration bond at 1365 cm–1 assigned to –COC– the ether bond [57]. Furthermore, the vibrational deformation of methyl ether within DMM is evident at 980–1220 cm–1, suggesting methanol adsorption on the catalyst surface to form methoxy groups, which subsequently desorb to yield CH3O– for condensation reactions [58]. The intensity of –COO– peak and the CH3O– peak of DMM gradually increased as the reaction time prolonging [59], which identified that first methanol was oxidized into FA and a minor amount of DME on the VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalyst, subsequently FA was oxidized to generate formic acid. Afterward, FA and methanol endure condensation to form DMM, and formic acid and methanol endure condensation to form MF. After 12 min, the reaction tended to be stable and the peak intensity remained almost unchanged, indicating that VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalyst had high catalytic activity. This observation is coherent with the above experimental results and confirmed the previous theoretical speculation regarding to the selective oxydehydrogenation of methanol to DMM by a one-step reaction. Based on the above results, a possible reaction mechanism of methanol oxydehydrogenation is shown in Fig. 10. Methanol and O2 were chemically adsorbed through vanadyl bond and oxygen vacancies on the vanadia-based catalyst surface, respectively [60]. One proton of methanol hydroxyl group transferred to the oxygen of vanadyl and vanadium reduced from V5+ to V4+, accompanied by the formation of oxygen vacancy (Fig. 10, step a) [10]. The partial reduction of the vanadium oxidation state was detected by XPS (Table 1 and Fig. S7), which was directly corelated with reducibility of Ce4+ to Ce3+. This indicates that the support is involved in the reaction process. Due to the loss of an extra hydrogen atom, the methoxy species undergoes a change into molecularly adsorbed formaldehyde, and this transformation is accompanied by the partial reduction of the second vanadium cation to V4+ (Fig. 10, step b). Formaldehyde can either continue to further transformation into dioxymethylene species or desorb as a product. dioxymethylene species reacts with methanol or the methoxy species to generate dimethoxymethane as a main product of the reaction (Fig. 10, step c). The dioxymethylene undergoes oxidation to produce the formate species, the formate species may undergo a transformation into formic acid and carbon monoxide, or it can react with methanol to produce methyl formate, further decomposition of formate species leads to the formation of CO and CO2 (Fig. 10, step d) [12]. Reoxidation of reduced V4+ and Ce3+ cations occurs when O2 is chemically adsorbed at the vacancy site. As shown in Table 1, the increase in chemisorbed oxygen species also improves the reoxidation process of the reduced cations, resulting in the formation of active sites that contain V5+ cations with terminal oxygen atoms. 4 Conclusion In summary, we precisely synthesized a series of VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalysts with different Zr/Ce molar ratios, which could effectively catalyze the oxydehydrogenation of methanol to dimethoxymethane. The introduction of Zr into CeO2 formed the Vn+/Ce–O–Zr sites to facilitate the adsorption and activation of methanol and O2, and their subsequent reaction produced formaldehyde, which acted as an intermediate for condensation reaction with methanol on the acidic sites of the VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalyst to produce DMM. Specifically, the presence of V5+ with terminal oxygen atom and oxygen vacancies demonstrated a synergistic capacity to facilitate the activation of oxygen species and cleavage of C−H and O−H bonds within the adsorbed methanol. By adjusting the Zr content, the oxygen vacancy concentration could be varied, leading to matching the reaction rates of methanol oxydehydrogenation and condensation, and VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 possessed the highest amount of Vn+/Ce–O–Zr sites showed the best catalytic activity for the oxydehydrogenation of methanol to DMM. coredata.dc:description: Metal oxide catalysts like ceria-supported vanadia (VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2) with different Zr contents were prepared by coupling ceria-zirconia solid solution and vanadia. Characterization revealed that the insertion of zirconia into ceria significantly improved catalytic activity due to the generation of more oxygen vacancies and distortion of the composite structure. The oxygen vacancy concentration initially increased with the increase of Zr (x= wt%) and peaked at x=0.7 and then decreased. The reliance of oxygen vacancy concentration in VOx/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalyst on their catalytic activity in methanol oxydehydrogenation was further investigated. Results indicated that oxygen vacancies not only activated oxygen species but also cleaved C–H bonds alongside V5+ active site contained terminal oxygen atoms for cleaving O–H and C–H bonds within the adsorbed methanol. The VOx/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 exhibited the best catalytic activity with the methanol conversion of 76 % and the dimethoxymethane selectivity of 96 % at 200 ℃ and atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed reactor.
